titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Larry Kramer Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:14

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (227 boxes) + 2 roll, 4 broadside folders, 2 record album storage
did.abstract: The collection documents the career of Larry Kramer as a playwright and author, an advocate for gay rights, and an activist in the fight against AIDS. The collection consists of writings, including manuscripts and drafts of plays, books, screenplays, and articles; AIDS-related material; diaries; correspondence; photographs; printed material; audiovisual material; and other papers. There is also substantial material relating to the founding of Gay Men's Health Crisis and the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (ACT UP) in particular, and to the AIDS movement in general.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The bulk of the materials are open for research.
Boxes 49-50, 234-236: Restricted material. Contact the appropriate curator for further information.
Boxes 37, 58, 178-181, 202-205, 229 (electronic materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

Boxes 29-30, 151-153, 189, 207, 228, 233 (audiovideo material) and 186 (reel to reel audiotapes): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: November 2016 Acquisition: purchased from Larry Kramer on the Donald Windham-Sandy Campbell Collection Endowment Fund.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into seven groupings: July 2003 Acquisition (Uncat MSS 520), July 2003 Acquisition (Uncat MSS 785), August 2007 Acquisition (Uncat MSS 975), and October 2008 Acquisition (Uncat MSS 1071), July 2011 Acquisition, February 2016 Acquisition, and November 2016 Acquisition.
Material within this collection has been organized by acquisition reflecting the fact that the collection has been acquired in increments over time.

Researchers should note that material within each acquisition overlaps with and/or relates to material found in other acquisitions. For instance, writings, correspondence, and material relating to AIDS activism can be found in most, if not all, of the groupings. In order to locate all relevant material within this collection, researchers will need to consult each acquisition described in the Collection Contents section.
Researchers should also note that similar material can be arranged differently in each acquisition, depending on how the material was organized when it was received by the library.

bioghist.head: Larry Kramer (1935- )
bioghist.p: Larry Kramer is an American playwright, author, public health advocate, and gay rights activist. He graduated from Yale University in 1957 with a B.A. in English, and is the author of several novels, including Faggots (1978), and plays, including The Normal Heart (1985) and Destiny of Me (1992), which explore themes related to gay life and the AIDS crisis. He has long been an outspoken advocate for gay rights and the fight against AIDS. He was a co-founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis in the early 1980s, and later founded the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (ACT UP) in 1987. Kramer is also the author of several motion picture screenplays, including an adaptation of Women in Love , for which he was nominated for an Academy Award in 1969. He is currently working on the manuscript of an historical work called The American People .

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Larry Kramer Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 520, Uncat MSS 785, Uncat MSS 975, Uncat MSS 1071.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, and competing priorities. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Box 153 is unused. Original videocassettes are now housed in box 233. Restricted fragile material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection documents the career of Larry Kramer as a playwright and author, an advocate for gay rights, and an activist in the fight against AIDS. The collection consists of writings, including manuscripts and drafts of plays, books, screenplays, and articles; AIDS-related material; diaries; correspondence; photographs; printed material; audiovisual material; and other papers. There is also substantial material relating to the founding of Gay Men's Health Crisis and the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (ACT UP) in particular, and to the AIDS movement in general.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Larry Kramer Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collection consists of correspondence, writings, photographs, printed material, audiotapes, videotapes, and other papers by or relating to Larry Kramer.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under six headings: AIDS Activism Files; Diaries; Writings; Family Papers; Audiovisual Material; Posters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files contain a wide range of material documenting the AIDS crisis and relating to Kramer's activism and advocacy in the fight against AIDS, including his work with Gay Men's Health Crisis and AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power. Material includes clippings, photocopies of articles, correspondence, medical reports, publications, conference programs, press material, newsletters, notes, and writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collection consists of correspondence, writings, Gay Men's Health Crisis files, notebooks, photographs, audio and visual recordings and other papers, which originated from Kramer's home in Connecticut.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence. II. Gay Men's Health Crisis. III. Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files consist largely of incoming and outgoing correspondence and email printouts, as well as assorted other papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in very rough chronological order. When material arrived, it was loose and grouped into boxes by year, beginning with the year 2000 and ending with the year 2007. The material within each box was found to span a broader range of dates, and so date ranges are supplied in the list below to better reflect the actual contents.

did.physdesc: (116 boxes) + 2 broadside folders, 8 rolls, 2 record albums

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Correspondence. II. Writings. III. Writing Files. IV. Professional Papers and Research Material. V. Personal and Other Papers. VI. Audiovisual Material.
These series represent broad groupings. Material within one series overlaps with material found in other series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collection consists of an extensive amount of drafts and manuscripts of and files relating to Larry Kramer's writings, including plays, screenplays, and books. Also found is correspondence, printed material, notes, and other files, stemming from Kramer's film work in the 1960s and 1970s, his AIDS advocacy and activism from the late 1970s to the present day, his AIDS-related research, and other professional activities. There are also some personal and family papers. This portion of the collection originated from Kramer's apartment in New York City.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three groupings: Chronological, General, and Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence consists of incoming and outgoing letters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This group of correspondence represents letters that were housed together in boxes according to year. The overall grouping by year has been maintained and the groupings have been arranged in rough chronological order, however letters within each grouping are not arranged in any order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent or original folder heading, which appears in quotes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in a very rough chronological order with original groupings left intact.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two audiocassettes: "What's Going On?" by Paul Willcocks (circa 1985) and an unlabeled cassette (circa 1980s).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to the creation of Kramer's writings and consists primarily of numerous copies of various drafts and manuscripts of his plays, screenplays, and books. For material relating more to the production, publication, and reception of Kramer's writings, see Writings Files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four groupings according to genre: Plays; Screenplays; Books; and Shorter Works and Other Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of material relating to the production, publication, and reception of Kramer's writings (including plays, screenplays, and books). Material includes correspondence, press material, clippings, reviews, royalty statements, notes, and photographs. For material relating more to the creation of Kramer's writings, see Writings, Drafts and Manuscripts.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to original audiocassettes is restricted. Reference copies may be requested.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a wide range of material relating broadly to Kramer's various professional activities, including his film work, his AIDS advocacy and activism, especially his work with Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC) and AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (ACT UP), and his non-literary writing. Material includes correspondence, printed material, notes and notebooks, research material, typescripts of articles and speeches, clippings of interviews and articles by and about Kramer, and other office files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight groupings: Notebooks; Film Project Files; Early Files; AIDS General; AIDS Activism; Research Material; Interviews, Articles, and Speeches; and Other Files.
Within the groupings, files are not arranged in any particular order.
